The upcoming Shura Council elections in 2010 were decided not to be under any national court supervision or international supervision. The General Secretary of the Policy Committee in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] Gamal Mubarak said in a press conference that, "This issue is governed by the law and the constitution which made it possible for civil society organizations to monitor the elections".<ref name="daralhayat"/> The Secretary of Education in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]], [[Mohamed Kamal]], said that the party welcomes the supervision of national organizations, but refuses international monitoring. He also added that the abolition of judicial supervision of elections does not affect the integrity of the elections.
The upcoming Shura Council elections in 2010 were decided not to be under any national court supervision or international supervision. The General Secretary of the Policy Committee in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] Gamal Mubarak said in a press conference that, "This issue is governed by the law and the constitution which made it possible for civil society organizations to monitor the elections".<ref name="daralhayat"/> The Secretary of Education in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]], [[Mohamed Kamal]], said that the party welcomes the supervision of national organizations, but refuses international monitoring. He also added that the abolition of judicial supervision of elections does not affect the integrity of the elections.
  +   +
